item.title: Ever changing seascapes
item.trailText: Beautiful seascapes capture the power and perpetual motion of ocean waves, rising up and crashing down as they near the Australian coast. Ray Collins, a coal miner until he turned to surf photography after an industrial injury, also focuses on the calmer and more serene moments he experiences in the sea
item.standFirst: Beautiful seascapes capture the power and perpetual motion of ocean waves, rising up and crashing down as they near the Australian coast. Ray Collins, a coal miner until he turned to surf photography after an industrial injury, also focuses on the calmer and more serene moments he experiences in the sea

displayImages.caption: A close-up of the water in New South Wales, Australia, gives it a frozen quality.

cards.title: That's me in the picture / I was the only one who didn’t suffer burns – my brother was lying on top of me
cards.rawTitle: I was the only one who didn’t suffer burns – my brother was lying on top of me

item.title: That’s me in the picture: Tammi Brownlee, aged 3, carried by George Girvan from a fire in south Boston, 1977
item.trailText: ‘I was the only one who didn’t suffer burns, because my brother was lying on top of me. I guess he was trying to protect me’
item.standFirst: ‘I was the only one who didn’t suffer burns, because my brother was lying on top of me. I guess he was trying to protect me’
item.body:
I don’t remember anything before the fire. It was in an apartment building and we lived on the second floor. No one knows how it started. I lost my brother and mother. I officially died three times of smoke inhalation in the first week and they had to resuscitate me. I had a tracheotomy for almost six months.

When I got out of hospital after eight or nine months I was nearly four, and went to live with my father in Arizona. He told me he threw me out of a window to save me, jumped out and broke his leg. It turns out he was never there. My aunt told me he was sitting in a park because my mother had kicked him out of the house; another aunt told me he was in a bar. Some speculated he might have started it.

My father was mean, and a drunk. When he drank he would blurt out things and I wouldn’t know whether they were true. He would say he’d started the fire hoping my brother would be saved and the rest of us would die. I can’t tell you how many times I’ve had broken bones or bruises; I couldn’t go to school for three weeks because I was concussed after he threw me against a wall. I lived with him on and off until I was 13. If I annoyed him, he would send me back to Massachusetts, to family on my mother’s side, and then he’d come and take me back to Arizona. I dreaded him coming to get me; I would hide behind a door hoping he wouldn’t see me.

When I was 13, I went to live with a relative again. We had an argument and she kicked me out. I lived on the streets of Boston for three months. A social worker, who was a customer at a restaurant where the cook used to sneak me food, put me in foster care.

I was about eight when my father showed me this photo, from the original newspaper article. I said he was lying: “There’s no way I would have peed myself!” When I was 18, after leaving foster care, I went to the library to look at it. I was trying to figure out if it was actually me. My aunt showed me some photos of me around that age and that’s when I realised.

I started researching, and one night in 2010 I got frustrated and hit my computer, and the photographer’s page came up. I emailed him. We appeared on the news and he took me to meet Alfred Chase, the firefighter who saved me. That’s when I found out what really happened.

He told me he crawled down a hallway and came across a “pile”, which he realised was my brother lying on top of me. He passed me to another firefighter, George Girvan, who was on a ladder up to our second-floor window, then went back for my brother. He and a family friend’s daughter who was staying with us, Debbie, came out without a pulse. They managed to resuscitate them, but they died hours later. My mother was burned over 90% of her body and passed away two weeks later. I was the only one who didn’t suffer burns, because my brother was lying on top of me. I guess he was trying to protect me. He was two days shy of his seventh birthday. It was a relief to finally find out what happened, but I cried. It reinforced how many times my father, who is now dead, had lied to me.

Now my boyfriend, whom I’ve been with for 15 years, is a firefighter. As annoying as it is that I can’t keep anything plugged in around the house because it might cause a fire, I feel safe.

• As told to Erica Buist.

Are you in a famous photograph? Email thatsme@theguardian.com.

displayImages.caption: 'No one knows how the fire started. I lost my brother and mother.' Photograph: Stanleyformanphotos.com
displayImages.altText: That's me: Tammi Brownlee
displayImages.cleanCaption: 'No one knows how the fire started. I lost my brother and mother.' Photograph: Stanleyformanphotos.com

cards.title: Creaturepedia / The best and strangest animal facts
cards.rawTitle: The best and strangest animal facts

item.title: The best and strangest animal facts
item.trailText: From the oriental fire-bellied toad’s ‘unken reflex’ to the porcupine fish’s ability to squirt blood out of its eyes, Adrienne Barman, author and illustrator of Creaturepedia, shares some very weird animal facts and stunning illustrations too
item.standFirst: From the oriental fire-bellied toad’s ‘unken reflex’ to the porcupine fish’s ability to squirt blood out of its eyes, Adrienne Barman, author and illustrator of Creaturepedia, shares some very weird animal facts and stunning illustrations too

displayImages.caption: Like gladiators, these animals exploit a number of cunning devices to defend themselves in the wild. Musk oxen, for example, work and operate as a pack, herding and charging towards their prey in groups of two or three dozen. These mammals have used this tactic to survive in the Arctic for thousands and thousands of years. The rubber boa, also known as the “two-headed snake”, tricks other animals into thinking its tail is its head. When a predator approaches, it curls up into a ball and hides its head under its body!  Photograph: Illustration: Adrienne Barman
displayImages.altText: creaturepedia1.jpg
displayImages.cleanCaption: Like gladiators, these animals exploit a number of cunning devices to defend themselves in the wild. Musk oxen, for example, work and operate as a pack, herding and charging towards their prey in groups of two or three dozen. These mammals have used this tactic to survive in the Arctic for thousands and thousands of years. The rubber boa, also known as the “two-headed snake”, tricks other animals into thinking its tail is its head. When a predator approaches, it curls up into a ball and hides its head under its body!

displayImages.caption: The oriental fire-bellied toad uses an even weirder defence strategy… At only 4-5cm in size, these amphibians rely on a clever ‘unken reflex’ to protect themselves against attacks. By revealing their bright red and black bellies, they warn predators they’re poisonous and may be deadly to eat Photograph: Illustration: Adrienne Barman
displayImages.altText: Creaturepedia2.jpg
displayImages.cleanCaption: The oriental fire-bellied toad uses an even weirder defence strategy… At only 4-5cm in size, these amphibians rely on a clever ‘unken reflex’ to protect themselves against attacks. By revealing their bright red and black bellies, they warn predators they’re poisonous and may be deadly to eat

displayImages.caption: From anteaters to armadillos, these prickly animals know how to keep predators at bay! The natural barbs, spikes and horns on their body act as in-built defences – great for putting off potential predators and stop them from being eaten Photograph: Illustration: Adrienne Barman
displayImages.altText: Creaturepedia3.jpg
displayImages.cleanCaption: From anteaters to armadillos, these prickly animals know how to keep predators at bay! The natural barbs, spikes and horns on their body act as in-built defences – great for putting off potential predators and stop them from being eaten

displayImages.caption: Porcupine fish are deadly for humans to eat, and yet they are served as a delicacy in some countries. One of the earliest records of porcupine fish poisoning was from Captain Cook, who ate some in 1774! Horned toads are talented reptiles, with a unique box of tricks for deterring predators. If blowing up like a balloon doesn’t confuse them, squirting blood from their eyes definitely will! They can spray this noxious liquid up to one metre Photograph: Illustration: Adrienne Barman
displayImages.altText: creaturepedia4.jpg
displayImages.cleanCaption: Porcupine fish are deadly for humans to eat, and yet they are served as a delicacy in some countries. One of the earliest records of porcupine fish poisoning was from Captain Cook, who ate some in 1774! Horned toads are talented reptiles, with a unique box of tricks for deterring predators. If blowing up like a balloon doesn’t confuse them, squirting blood from their eyes definitely will! They can spray this noxious liquid up to one metre

displayImages.caption: Fierceness is a trait found in animals all over the planet… and a creature’s ferocity bears no relation to its size – as those who have had a run-in with a horsefly will testify! From the bloodthirsty baboon to the tantrum-prone Tasmanian devil, here are some animals you might wish to give a wide berth… Photograph: Illustration: Adrienne Barman
displayImages.altText: Creaturepedia5.jpg
displayImages.cleanCaption: Fierceness is a trait found in animals all over the planet… and a creature’s ferocity bears no relation to its size – as those who have had a run-in with a horsefly will testify! From the bloodthirsty baboon to the tantrum-prone Tasmanian devil, here are some animals you might wish to give a wide berth…

displayImages.caption: As you might have guessed from their name, Goliath tiger fish are enormous! These underwater giants can grow up to five feet and have around 32 serrated, razor-sharp teeth, each of which can be up to one inch long. If tiger fish are one of scariest animals you’ll meet underwater, Grizzly bears are one of the most terrifying to face on land. Thanks to their size, which ranges from 1.5 to 2.5 metres, these majestic, solitary animals are positioned right at the top of the food chain Photograph: Illustration: Adrienne Barman
displayImages.altText: Creaturepedia6.jpg
displayImages.cleanCaption: As you might have guessed from their name, Goliath tiger fish are enormous! These underwater giants can grow up to five feet and have around 32 serrated, razor-sharp teeth, each of which can be up to one inch long. If tiger fish are one of scariest animals you’ll meet underwater, Grizzly bears are one of the most terrifying to face on land. Thanks to their size, which ranges from 1.5 to 2.5 metres, these majestic, solitary animals are positioned right at the top of the food chain

displayImages.caption: Kestrels are excellent hunters, who hover above their prey, waiting for the right moment to attack. Another well-adapted predator is the tiger shark: their heightened sense of sight and smell, along with a powerful, shell-crunching jaw, makes it easy for them to detect and hunt their prey. And they’re not fussy about what they eat either – researchers have found a whole medley of strange things in their stomach, from license plates to rubber tyres! Photograph: Illustration: Adrienne Barman
displayImages.altText: Creaturepedia7.jpg
displayImages.cleanCaption: Kestrels are excellent hunters, who hover above their prey, waiting for the right moment to attack. Another well-adapted predator is the tiger shark: their heightened sense of sight and smell, along with a powerful, shell-crunching jaw, makes it easy for them to detect and hunt their prey. And they’re not fussy about what they eat either – researchers have found a whole medley of strange things in their stomach, from license plates to rubber tyres!

displayImages.caption: Size matters… in fact, if you’re an animal, it often decides where you lie in the food chain! Giants such as the ostrich have a natural advantage when it comes to hunting – their kick is powerful enough to kill a human, and they’re quick on their feet too, thanks to their five-metre-long stride. Giant Pacific octopuses may not have the speed of an ostrich, but thankfully they’re experts at hiding. Special pigment cells in their skin allow them to change colours and textures according to their surroundings, camouflaging them against corals, plants, and rocks  Photograph: Illustration: Adrienne Barman
displayImages.altText: Giants 1
displayImages.cleanCaption: Size matters… in fact, if you’re an animal, it often decides where you lie in the food chain! Giants such as the ostrich have a natural advantage when it comes to hunting – their kick is powerful enough to kill a human, and they’re quick on their feet too, thanks to their five-metre-long stride. Giant Pacific octopuses may not have the speed of an ostrich, but thankfully they’re experts at hiding. Special pigment cells in their skin allow them to change colours and textures according to their surroundings, camouflaging them against corals, plants, and rocks

displayImages.caption: The Goliath bird-eating spider is widely considered the biggest spider in the world. It’s ginormous! The fangs of these tarantulas can pierce a human’s skin, but despite their name, they’re actually much more likely to eat earthworms than birds Photograph: Illustration: Adrienne Barman
displayImages.altText: Giants 2
displayImages.cleanCaption: The Goliath bird-eating spider is widely considered the biggest spider in the world. It’s ginormous! The fangs of these tarantulas can pierce a human’s skin, but despite their name, they’re actually much more likely to eat earthworms than birds

displayImages.caption: At around 30 metres in length, and with tongues the size of elephants, the blue whale is the largest animal on the planet! It’s also one of the loudest too: in good conditions, it’s thought that blue whales can hear each other up to 1,600 kilometres away Photograph: Illustration: Adrienne Barman
displayImages.altText: Giants 3
displayImages.cleanCaption: At around 30 metres in length, and with tongues the size of elephants, the blue whale is the largest animal on the planet! It’s also one of the loudest too: in good conditions, it’s thought that blue whales can hear each other up to 1,600 kilometres away

displayImages.caption: Giant oceanic manta rays can grow up to 9 metres wide – in fact they’re so huge that there are hardly any aquariums big enough to house them! These breathtaking giants are rarely seen in the open water, although unfortunately they often get caught in fishing nets Photograph: Illustration: Adrienne Barman
displayImages.altText: Giants 4
displayImages.cleanCaption: Giant oceanic manta rays can grow up to 9 metres wide – in fact they’re so huge that there are hardly any aquariums big enough to house them! These breathtaking giants are rarely seen in the open water, although unfortunately they often get caught in fishing nets

displayImages.caption: Meet the green anaconda and reticulated python: the two biggest snake species in existence! These sneaky serpents are best adapted to hunting in water – with their eyes and nasal openings on top of their head, they can hide below the surface and wait for the perfect moment to strike Photograph: Illustration: Adrienne Barman
displayImages.altText: Giants 5
displayImages.cleanCaption: Meet the green anaconda and reticulated python: the two biggest snake species in existence! These sneaky serpents are best adapted to hunting in water – with their eyes and nasal openings on top of their head, they can hide below the surface and wait for the perfect moment to strike

cards.title: Fashion for all ages / Workout wear

item.title: Fashion for all ages: workout wear
item.trailText: How to work workout-wear, whatever your age
item.standFirst:
Give your workout-wear a boost by investing in bright block colours and athleisure-inspired pieces. Sylviane’s jogging bottoms are a particular winner here: take away the water bottle and trainers, swap the tracksuit top for a white shirt, and you have some viable work trousers. Natalie’s Fila jacket is perfect for running, as well as for everyday. Ava looks cool in her graphic patterned leggings, and a long-sleeve jumper such as Lisskulla’s is ideal for yoga classes. Seasoned gym bunnies, meanwhile, will appreciate Elina’s coordinated outfit: those old leggings and baggy T-shirts can be relegated to the bin.
Melanie Wilkinson

Photographs: David Newby for the Guardian. Styling: Melanie Wilkinson. Fashion assistant: Hannah Davidson. Makeup: Lisa Stokes using Guerlain and Eylure, assisted by Saskia Bannister. Hair: Ernesto Montenovo at Phamous using Bumble and bumble. Models: Sylviane at Ugly, Lisskulla at Models1, Ava at Storm, Natalie at Elite, Elina at Profile.

displayImages.caption: Natalie wears windbreaker, £85, by Fila, from urbanoutfitters.com. Bra top, £22.95, gap.co.uk. Shorts, £32, about-underwear.com. Headphones, £39, urbanears.com. Trainers, £65, by Nike, from urbanoutfitters.com

cards.title: 3D printer lends a hand to girl born without fingers
cards.rawTitle: 3D printer lends a hand to girl born without fingers

item.title: 3D printer lends a hand to girl born without fingers
item.trailText: Eight-year-old Isabella Rudd from Dartford, who was born with no fingers on her right arm, has been given new mobility by a prosthetic created by a 3D printer.
item.standFirst: Eight-year-old Isabella Rudd from Dartford, who was born with no fingers on her right arm, has been given new mobility by a prosthetic created by a 3D printer. The hand, built from biodegradable plastic, cost the Rudd family only £50. Isabella can now pick up objects and ride a bike, which she couldn't do before

displayImages.caption: 620x372 trailpic for printedhand Photograph: guardian.co.uk

item.title: Photo highlights of the day: from Cannes to dune racing in Libya
item.trailText: The Guardian’s picture editors bring you a selection of the best photographs from around the world including the Cannes film festival, maneki-neko in Tokyo, off-roading in Libya and the Vivid Sydney festival
item.standFirst: The Guardian’s picture editors bring you a selection of the best photographs from around the world including the Cannes film festival, maneki-neko figurines in Tokyo, off-roading in Libya and the Vivid Sydney festival

displayImages.altText: Tokyo, Japan The maneki neko at Gotokuji temple. Thought to bring luck and prosperity to their owners, these cats are frequently found outside businesses and within homes
displayImages.cleanCaption: Tokyo, Japan The maneki-neko at Gotokuji temple. Thought to bring luck and prosperity to their owners, the cat figurines are frequently found outside businesses and within homes

displayImages.caption: Kathmandu, Nepal Residents sleep under an awning. Almost 8,500 people have been confirmed dead after the earthquake disasters that destroyed more than half a million homes. There are just weeks to go until the monsoon rains Photograph: Ishara S Kodikara/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Kathmandu, Nepal Residents sleep under an awning. Nearly 8,500 people have been confirmed dead after the earthquake disasters that destroyed more than half a million homes. There are just weeks to go until the monsoon rains
displayImages.cleanCaption: Kathmandu, Nepal Residents sleep under an awning. Almost 8,500 people have been confirmed dead after the earthquake disasters that destroyed more than half a million homes. There are just weeks to go until the monsoon rains

displayImages.caption: Valparaíso region, Chile Demonstrators take part in a march calling for more student participation in educational reforms approved by the Chilean parliament. The march, which was organised by the Confederation of Chilean Students among others, also , commemorated two students who were murdered last week Photograph: Jorge Villegas/Xinhua Press/Corbis
displayImages.altText: Valparaíso region, Chile A demonstrator shouts slogans during a march organised by the Confederation of Chilean Students and other social organisations, demanding more participation in reforms installed in the congress, and in homage of the two students murdered last week
displayImages.cleanCaption: Valparaíso region, Chile Demonstrators take part in a march calling for more student participation in educational reforms approved by the Chilean parliament. The march, which was organised by the Confederation of Chilean Students among others, also , commemorated two students who were murdered last week

displayImages.caption: Phnom Penh, Cambodia Participants take part in a horse race during a ceremony at Pring Ka-Ek village. The races which also involve oxcarts are part of local tradition of paying respect to the Neakta Pring Ka-Ek (spirit house) to help people overcome diseases and for abundant rice harvests Photograph: Mak Remissa/EPA
displayImages.altText: Phnom Penh, Cambodia Horses race during a ceremony at Pring Ka-Ek village, where oxcart and horse racing is organised to continue local traditions of paying respect to the Neakta Pring Ka-Ek (spirit house) to help people overcome diseases and for abundant rice harvests and other agricultural yields
displayImages.cleanCaption: Phnom Penh, Cambodia Participants take part in a horse race during a ceremony at Pring Ka-Ek village. The races which also involve oxcarts are part of local tradition of paying respect to the Neakta Pring Ka-Ek (spirit house) to help people overcome diseases and for abundant rice harvests

displayImages.caption: Tbilisi, Georgia A soldier traverses the Vaziani training area as part of joint exercises involving 600 US and Georgian troops. The exercises are aimed at enhancing the two countries’ military relationship as well as the training of Georgian troops for the Nato response force Photograph: Vano Shlamov/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Tbilisi, Georgia A serviceman at the Vaziani training area. Some 600 US and Georgian troops are taking part in joint exercises aimed at enhancing the two countries’ military relationship and training Georgian troops for contribution to the Nato response force
displayImages.cleanCaption: Tbilisi, Georgia A soldier traverses the Vaziani training area as part of joint exercises involving 600 US and Georgian troops. The exercises are aimed at enhancing the two countries’ military relationship as well as the training of Georgian troops for the Nato response force

displayImages.caption: Qarabuli, Libya Young Libyans are driving on the sand dunes in their 4X4 vehicles, 35 miles east of the capital, Tripoli. Drivers race each other every Friday Photograph: Mahmud Turkia/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Qarabuli, Libya Young Libyans are driving on the sand dunes in their four-wheel drive vehicles, 35 miles east of the capital, Tripoli. In a weekly escape from the violence gripping their country, drivers race each other every Friday
displayImages.cleanCaption: Qarabuli, Libya Young Libyans are driving on the sand dunes in their 4X4 vehicles, 35 miles east of the capital, Tripoli. Drivers race each other every Friday

displayImages.caption: New York, US Cuban wrestler Liván López Azcuy takes on David Taylor of the US in the men’s freestyle74kg class during Salsa in the Square Photograph: Jason Szenes/EPA
displayImages.altText: Cuba’s Liván López Azcuy and the USA’s David Taylor compete in the men’s freestyle wrestling 74kg class during Salsa in the Square in Times Square in New York
displayImages.cleanCaption: New York, US Cuban wrestler Liván López Azcuy takes on David Taylor of the US in the men’s freestyle74kg class during Salsa in the Square

displayImages.caption: Sydney, Australia People watch as the Museum of Contemporary Art is illuminated during a preview of installations at the Vivid Sydney festival of light, music and ideas Photograph: Paul Miller/EPA

displayImages.caption: Srinagar, Indian Kashmir Muslims pray as a holy relic believed to be hair from the beard of Muhammad is displayed at the Hazratbal shrine on the Friday following the festival of Mehraj-u-Alam, which marks the ascension of the prophet to heaven Photograph: Farooq Khan/EPA
displayImages.altText: Srinagar, Indian Kashmir Muslims pray as a holy relic believed to be hair from the beard of the prophet Muhammad is displayed at the Hazratbal shrine on the Friday following the Muslim festival of Mehraj-u-Alam, believed to mark the ascension of the prophet to heaven
displayImages.cleanCaption: Srinagar, Indian Kashmir Muslims pray as a holy relic believed to be hair from the beard of Muhammad is displayed at the Hazratbal shrine on the Friday following the festival of Mehraj-u-Alam, which marks the ascension of the prophet to heaven

displayImages.caption: California, US The crew of the Hydroptère yacht on a test run off the coast near Los Angeles. The boat is a hydrofoil trimaran designed by Alain Thébault and will attempt to break the sailing record from LA to Hawaii of four and a half days Photograph: Mark Ralston/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: California, US The crew of the Hydroptère yacht on a testrun off Los Angeles. The boat is a hydrofoil trimaran designed by Alain Thébault and will attempt to break the sailing record from LA to Hawaii of four and a half days
displayImages.cleanCaption: California, US The crew of the Hydroptère yacht on a test run off the coast near Los Angeles. The boat is a hydrofoil trimaran designed by Alain Thébault and will attempt to break the sailing record from LA to Hawaii of four and a half days
